snippet.title: A: Lightbox for images and youtube videos which works on the IPAD
snippet.description: Fancybox did the trick. It "lightboxes" youtube videos through an iFrame, which is key because youtube is able to sort out that your browser belongs to an iPad/iPhone and then converts the media to a non-flash format. Fancybox in action on my soccer toy's website …

snippet.title: A: Trying to find substring in string on sql server
snippet.description: Try this DECLARE @myparameter as varchar(500) set @myparameter = 'Basketball & Soccer & Volleyball' DECLARE @cleanparam as varchar(500) SELECT @cleanparam = REPLACE(@myparameter,'&amp … ;','&') --<\----put some trick here :) SELECT @cleanparam = REPLACE(@cleanparam,'&','&') SELECT @cleanparam = REPLACE(@cleanparam,'"','"') SELECT @cleanparam = REPLACE(@cleanparam, '©', '©') SELECT @cleanparam = REPLACE(@cleanparam, '«', '«') SELECT @cleanparam …

snippet.title: A: how to find longest match of a string including a focus word in python
snippet.description: of two strings, you could do something like: > [LCS(input, s) for s in ss] ['i play soccer and ', ' eat pizza ', ' and eat pizza ', ' eat pizza on the weekend'] Then, it sounds like you're … combination of strings would you use to create your output string? Based on your comments, I think this should do the trick: > parts = [s for s in [LCS(input, s) for s in ss] if s.find(focus_word) > -1 …

snippet.title: A: Can this sql query be simplified?
snippet.description: The trick is to use aliases so that you can use the same tables multiple times: SELECT p.* FROM Person p INNER JOIN SportsPerPerson spa ON p.Id = spa.PersonId INNER JOIN Sports sa … ON spa.SportsId = sa.Id INNER JOIN SportsPerPerson spb ON p.Id = spb.PersonId INNER JOIN Sports sb ON spb.SportsId = sb.Id WHERE sa.Name = 'Tennis' AND sb.Name = 'Soccer' …

snippet.title: Q: Keep mobile browser from showing elements outside content bounds?
snippet.description: like it if the browser could only zoom out only as wide as the content container. Is this possible? I could obviously put a overflow-x:hidden on the div but then it would actually cut off the soccer … ball altogether. Would be nice if the mobile browser could only zoom out this far: I know that technically the image (in this case) is part of the 'content' since it's in the content div. I'm wondering if there are any layout or css tricks that could be used to achieve what I'm looking for. …
